ygData.subject: Fwd: [neat] Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello, Thanks for your feedback. I read this post on p-values that you included a link to. It doesn t say that p-values are utterly uninformative, but it does

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=bxgyy_c_SGzfDASPlHu6YB4vPob3a5EG-yGjC4Btwk_l0lxUzNFE

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello, 

Thanks for your feedback. 

I read this post on p-values that you =
included a link to. It doesn't say that p-values are utterly uninformative,=
 but it does point out a lot of problems with them. 

I do not believe in a=
 magical threshold (e.g. p=3D0.5), so I escape most of the criticism of thi=
s article. But I do think p-values are important. I agree that effect size =
should also be important=85.but I was under the impression that both are im=
portant for different reasons (one does not replace the other because they =
serve different purposes). This article agrees, saying you need both, since=
 effect sizes don't focus on whether the effect is true "in the world"; ins=
tead, effect sizes just describe the size of the effect in the sampe: http:=
//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effect_size

Do you disagree?

Finally, most (all?)=
 papers do report effect sizes: they report the mean/median +/- variance/st=
d/stderr for treatment A vs. B, as well as a p-value. The effect size is th=
e difference in the averages of A & B, no? The problem is that not all pape=
rs (in our field, especially) report the p-value in addition, which I (and =
wikipedia) think they should. 

I'd be interested to hear why you think p-v=
alues are meaningless, and what you would propose instead to ascertain whet=
her the sample reflects the true distribution. 

PS. The most worrisome sec=
tion of this post for me is this: 

"But now suppose we=92ve learned our le=
sson: and so, chastened, we abandon our arbitrary threshold a value and loo=
k instead at the exact p value associated with our predictor variable, as m=
any writers have advocated. And let=92s supposed that it is impressively lo=
w, say p =3D 0.00073. We conclude, correctly, that if the null hypothesis w=
ere true (which we never really believed in the first place) then the data =
we actually obtained in our sample would have been pretty unlikely. So, fol=
lowing standard practice, we conclude that the probability that the null hy=
pothesis is true is only 0.00073. Right? Wrong. We have confused the probab=
ility of the data if you are given the hypothesis,  P(Data|H0), which is p,=
 with its inverse probability P(H0|Data), the probability of the hypothesis=
 if you are given the data, which is something else entirely. Ironically, w=
e can compute the inverse probability from the original probability =96 but=
 only if we adopt a Bayesian approach that allows for =93subjective=94 prob=
abilities. That approach says that you begin the study of some prior belief=
 (expressed as a probability) in a given hypothesis, and adjust that in lig=
ht of your new data."

I admit that I do tend to do this: "following standa=
rd practice, we conclude that the probability that the null hypothesis is t=
rue is only 0.00073." 

I'd be happy to switch to the Bayesian approach, th=
ough I don't know much about it yet. Do you know of a nice, short, introduc=
tion to this paradigm?


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Comp=
uter Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

ogroups.com
> 
> Hi Jeff,
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jcl=
une@...> wrote:
> 
> > I'm of course not opposed to quantitative tests. I'm=
 actually a big fan of them if they are informative. Also, if someone does =
make a quantitative claim (e.g. performance is higher with algorithm X than=
 Y), then I insist on a p-value as a reviewer. Statistics and quantificatio=
n are important scientific tools, and in most cases should be present.
> 
>=
 p-values are utterly uninformative (http://ecodevoevo.blogspot.com/2013/05=
/lets-abandon-significance-tests.html?spref=3Dtw&m=3D1). Ask for effect siz=
e instead. :-)
> 
> --
> Randal S. Olson
> 
> Computer Science PhD Student
=
> Michigan State University
> E-mail: rso@...
> http://www.rand=
alolson.com
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_A1195010-743E-4E12-822B-FDFE0132C3F6

iv id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Hi Jeff,<br>
<br>
--- In <a href=3D"mailto:neat%40ya=
hoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrot=
e:<br>
<br>
> I'm of course not opposed to quantitative tests. I'm actua=
lly a big fan of them if they are informative. Also, if someone does make a=
 quantitative claim (e.g. performance is higher with algorithm X than Y), t=
hen I insist on a p-value as a reviewer. Statistics and quantification are =
important scientific tools, and in most cases should be present.<br>
<br>
p=
-values are utterly uninformative (<a href=3D"http://ecodevoevo.blogspot.co=
m/2013/05/lets-abandon-significance-tests.html?spref=3Dtw&m=3D1">http:/=
/ecodevoevo.blogspot.com/2013/05/lets-abandon-significance-tests.html?spref=
=3Dtw&m=3D1</a>). Ask for effect size instead. :-)<br>
<br>
